contents:
On Saturday, July 30th, five of our FASCA members attended the Teen Safety Symposium hosted by the Dallas Police Department. We started off the day by learning about online safety and human trafficking from DPD detectives, officers, and members. During our lunch break, attendees were able to visit different stands, with each stand touching on important topics including sexual health/education, suicide prevention, mental health, and LGBTQ+ representation. Each stand also gave multiple opportunities to get involved with the community through their respective programs. Afterwards, we had other officers give talks on recognizing drugs/alcohol and personal safety. Throughout the event, there were also opportunities to win prizes from a raffle.
Overall, I gained a lot of valuable information from attending the Teen Safety Symposium. Many of the topics that the DPD touched on during the event had memorable lessons that we all walked away with. It was definitely eye-opening to know that just how many Internet-related and human trafficking crimes were happening right in here in Dallas. For many attendees, the talk on online safety was the most helpful. Since a lot of teens spend a good amount of time online, it was definitely important to address the prevalence of Internet crimes and how to protect ourselves.
title: Safety Symposium hosted by the Dallas Police Department

contents: For this year’s China Heritage Camp, FASCA members and teachers planned several classes and activities for campers and their families to learn more & immerse themselves in Chinese culture. The three-day camp consisted of language, dance, cooking, yo-yo, and culture courses, with an exciting performance at the closing ceremony.
title: 2022 China Camp at Tulsa, OK

contents:
On Saturday, July 16th, 2022 the Greater Dallas Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce hosted a Chinese New Year Charity Gala in July at the Renaissance Hotel in Addison. Teachers Shu Lam and Sara Haviland guided 5 FASCA students in setting up the facility by putting programs and tiger centerpieces on the tables. Before the Gala started Teacher Rosa Lu stopped by to demonstrate techniques of selling raffle tickets. 2 new FASCA members showed up for the second shift while 2 for the morning shift went home. Teachers Shu Lam and Dolly Chen led the second shift of 5 FASCA members. The Gala began with a loud festive lion dance in the banquet room. All FASCA members were busy selling raffle tickets to around 650 guests while teachers helped with ripping raffle tickets and placing them securely into the spinning drum and taking pictures. We helped distribute prize lists and locate small prizes for the lucky winners. At the end of the gala, we cleaned up by gathering programs, collecting envelopes left for the purchases of the tiger centerpieces as well as putting away any unsold ones.
Overall I had fun volunteering at the event even though it was a long day. I thought selling the raffle tickets was challenging because not everyone wanted to buy from me. At first, I felt discouraged but then I learned not to take it personally and tried my best. After all, it was for a good cause since a part of the proceed goes to help international exchange students study in Dallas. I also learned that by working with fellow FASCA members in doing anything we can accomplish tasks more efficiently and have fun.
title: Greater Dallas Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce hosted a Chinese New Year Charity Gala

contents: Please congratulate the following student council members elected yesterday, they will serve in the 2022-2023 school year. President : Jason Ky Sr. Vice President: Jesse Wang, Amy Wang, Alison Kao, Isabella Feng, Aimee Hsu, Edison Tsai
title: Student council members 2022-2023 school year

contents:
On Memorial Day, around 100 parents, students, teachers, alumni, and guests gathered to celebrate the accomplishments of 12 high school graduates and send them off to college. It took place on a windy day in a pavilion at Frisco Commons Park. The teachers started off the event by introducing themselves and elaborating on upcoming dates and events. Then, all attendees enjoyed the potluck. About an hour later, the annual election for the student council began. 7 candidates gave speeches, and the student population voted to show their support. All 7 candidates were selected to serve in the 2022-2023 school year. Next, the high school graduates lined up to share their experiences and express how FASCA has impacted them. Afterwards, former students lined up and shared their experiences in college. The event came to an end with a couple performances. Forest Haviland performed “太湖船” and “月亮代表我的心” on erhu. Lastly, several current and former students gave a Chinese yo-yo performance. Everyone enjoyed this gathering and had a lot of fun! Good luck to all of our FASCA seniors, and happy summer!
Thank you! parents and students, we had more than 100 people attend the graduation party, including 14 former FASCA members, welcome back! Here are some pictures featuring former students, parents and current members.
title: 歡送畢業生及選舉

contents: 2022 support Taiwan to join WHA rally in downtown Dallas - What a wonderful event we participated in on May 7th and it’s a great honor to be part of it. FASCA had a total of 33 people including students, parents and teachers come support this event. Deputy Director Carol Huang 黄依莉 副主任 from Culture Center of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston was present and showed support along with many members of Chinese clubs and local leaders. Congresswoman Eddie Bernice Johnson spoke to the rally with encouragement. Despite the differences, we all share the same love for Taiwan. We all wish there is a better tomorrow for Taiwan. What we FASCA can support and offer is “Oh Yeah!” bringing love、energy 、enthusiasm to you all and the community. Thank you to the organizations such as the Federation of Chinese Organization of DFW, GDTCC, and GFCBW for organizing this event. 感謝主辦單位: 達福地區中華社團聯誼會, 達福台灣商會, 世界華人工商婦女企管協會
title: 2022 support Taiwan to join WHA rally in downtown Dallas

contents:
On Saturday, February 26, 18 FASCA students, 4 FASCA teachers, Teacher Yuh-Sin Lee, Teacher Eliza Tsai-lin, and the Carroll ISD Chinese club performed at Highland Springs Senior Living. All performers did a great job of representing Chinese culture and teaching the audience at Highland Springs about Chinese New Year! The first performance was a lion dance, which was performed by both FASCA members and the Carroll ISD Chinese Club. The bright colors of the lion costumes and the amazing choreography made the entire room more festive!
The next act was a skit that told the story of the terrifying monster, Nian, and how the villagers found out it was afraid of loud noises and bright colors, teaching the audience about the Chinese New Year legend. The third act, the New World Dance, was performed by 4 FASCA students. The choreography, costumes, and headdresses were very unique, and displayed the culture of Taiwan. After that, Bella Feng performed a Mendelssohn violin solo. The sword dance, performed by 3 FASCA students, was a very interesting presentation of Chinese culture.
Next, Jackson Wang performed a euphonium solo and the FASCA students then performed the “I Believe” dance. Finally, a choir consisting of multiple FASCA parents and students, as well as violin and piano players, performed “The Moon Represents My Heart,” and “The New Year Song.” Overall, I think the event was extremely successful, and the audience at Highland Springs Senior living, over 60 people, definitely enjoyed the performances! Thank you to all parents, members, and teachers who participated and put in time and effort into this event!
title: Lunar New Year Celebration at Highland Springs

contents:
The Southlake Spring Festival was a Lunar New Year centered community event held on February 20th, 2022 after being postponed by the snowstorm the previous Saturday. Approximately 3,500 people attended this year, including 25 FASCA students, 5 FASCA teachers, and multiple parents. Food, music, and performances were all enjoyable aspects of the festival. FASCA was given a booth to set where, where there were three main elements: riddles, prizes, and origami butterflies. FASCA students and parents alike helped to make sure the stand ran smoothly. Festival participants that guessed the answer to the riddles correctly would be awarded a prize, and would have the chance to pick out a butterfly headband that FASCA helped handmake. Towards the end, we also began to teach kids how to fold their own butterflies.
This event was one of the longest FASCA events I’ve attended, and also one of the most enjoyable. Having the opportunity to talk to new people, bond with members, and seeing the smiles on kids’ faces after putting antennae onto their origami butterflies made the time pass by too quickly. I believe that this event was a great experience and opportunity for FASCA to become more involved with the DFW community.
title: 2022 Southlake Spring Festival

contents:
February 5, 2022, due to the winter storm affecting the DFW area, FASCA held another online Zoom practice for the Highland Springs Senior Living event scheduled for February 26th. There were 23 students, teachers, and parents participating in the practice. The session began with reviewing the full New World Dance video made by Alison Kao, then moving onto the detailed practice video. Then, the members were split into breakout rooms to work on their individual events — including MC-ing, skit, dance, etc. Afterwards, the members were able to do small-group practices of the 賀新年 ＆ 我的未來不是夢. The FASCA teachers were able to touch-up on students’ pronunciation and successfully bring the song together.
As we had already begun the learning stage for the dance, event, and songs, this meeting was important to polish and perfect them for the upcoming event. Alison’s well-paced video made it easy for me to follow along and learn the steps quickly. Being able to meet with our event groups allowed for scheduling of further practice, as well as brainstorming of ideas to make the performance clearer or better-executed. With the help of the FASCA teachers clarifying the lyrics and melody, as well as the focused breakout rooms, allowed many people were able to pick up on the song’s pronunciation and catch up to the tempo of 賀新年 ＆ 我的未來不是夢. I believe that this practice gave us the chance to be more fully prepared for the February 26th performance.
title: 2022 Southlake Spring Festival

contents: Today, we gathered together at the Dallas Chinese Community Center to celebrate New Year’s Day. FASCA students, parents, and staff attended the Raise the Flag and PVSA Award Ceremonies. 22 FASCA members were awarded the President’s Award. Students also performed “月亮代表我的心” and “I believe”. Congratulations to all award winners and Happy New Year!
title: 2022 Dallas Chinese Community Center New Year Celebration

contents: Nov. 7, a special person spend his precious time together with us. Mr. Hilliam, a FBI agent who has over 30-year experience dealing with crimes, currently hate crimes. Statistically speaking, hate crimes has been increasing because they are started to be reported. But Mr. Hilliam states that this can’t tell anything, it only shows that the idea of reporting hate crimes has been increasing. In short, Mr. Hilliam hopes everyone can use their right to protect themselves. In addition, “No matter what major you’re in, the way to get into FBI is to get a master degree,” Mr. Hilliam said. He encouraged that we as students should hold every chance to learn skills from different fields. However, we had a fun time with Mr. Hilliam, and learned more about the FBI agent, this career.
title: 2021 Chat with FBI agent - Mr. Hilliam

contents: This past Saturday, October 24, 2021, a few of our Dallas FASCA members drove down to Houston to listen to Secretary Elaine Chao. She told us about her background and her journey to where is she now. We even received books she wrote herself. It was an amazing experiencing, and quite fascinating to watch Secretary Chao talk about what she is dedicated to.
title: 2021 Secretary Elaine Chao speech in Houston

contents: This past Sunday, October 10th, 22 FASCA members gathered at the Dallas Chinese Community Center for the annual Double Tenth Celebration. Members set up the facility, raised flags, distributed food, and helped clean up. Overall, we all enjoyed celebrating Taiwan and this important holiday!
title: 2021 Taiwan Double Tenth Celebration

contents: Saturday October 16, 2021, 11 FASCA members, 4 teachers and 5 parents came together to volunteer at the North Texas Food Bank. For most members it was our first time. I can say we were all full of anticipation of what was about to take place. The volunteer coordinator gave everyone different tasks along the conveyor belt packing food into boxes that would be distributed to families around the metroplex. Everyone worked hard. We packed 16 pallets containing 768 boxes that equated to 17,280 meals. At the end of the shift we were all exhausted but seeing these numbers made me proud to have contributed in the fight against hunger along with my fellow FASCA members at the North Texas Food Bank.
title: FASCA - North Texas Food Bank

contents: Today we had our first FASCA meeting for 2021-2022! We had about 35 FASCA members in attendance, along with our parents and teachers. We went over general information, met the council members, introduced a new volunteer opportunity, and played games. It was great to see both old and new faces and get to know our new FASCA members better. Looking forward to a productive and fun year!
title: First FASCA meeting for 2021-2022!
